awd_titl_txt: Excellence in Research:  Investigation of RECQ1 helicase in DNA transactions upon oxidative stress
awd_abstract_narration:
The characteristics of each cell are defined by its DNA, a double-stranded helical molecule composed of two intertwined single strands of DNA. During the normal course of life cells sustain DNA damage, which must be repaired to maintain genetic integrity. This project will investigate how RECQ1, a DNA helicase that separates the two strands of DNA, helps repair DNA damage and maintain genome stability. RecQ helicases are present in all kingdoms of life and therefore this work will have broad relevance. This research will promote the careers of both graduate and undergraduate students. The work will provide opportunities to earn course credits for Directed Research or for an Honors thesis in the Department of Biochemistry and Molecular Biology at Howard University. Hands-on training in fundamental laboratory skills and interdisciplinary research training will prepare students for success in graduate education and in their future scientific careers in academia or in industrial biotechnology. The PI also performs outreach to broaden participation of women in science through the American Association of University Women, the NIH Women of Color in Science, and through another NSF initiative called HU-ADVANCE-IT.

The central hypothesis of this project is that RECQ1 acts as a barrier against genetic instability triggered by oxidative stress and the functional association of RECQ1 with oxidatively damaged chromatin ensures faithful expression and propagation of genetic information. The first aim is to establish the role of RECQ1 in activation of DNA damage response to oxidative stress and in replication fork progression during repair of oxidative DNA damage. In the second aim, unbiased biochemical and cellular approaches will be employed to determine catalytic activities of RECQ1 and its interacting protein partners that allow it to facilitate repair of oxidative DNA damage. The final aim will test the impact of RECQ1 on transcriptional response to oxidative DNA damage and whether this is mediated through specific binding to genomic regions susceptible to oxidation or form G-quadruplexes. Collectively, this research will ascertain the exact role of RECQ1 helicase under oxidative stress at the levels of replication, repair and transcriptional control. This knowledge will also help determine whether different RecQ family members have functional redundancies or whether they have specialized functions that may be critical in regulating oxidative (and other genotoxic) stress in the cell.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Oxidative stress, caused by reactive oxygen species (ROS), poses a significant challenge to genomic integrity. ROS, produced during normal cellular metabolism and through environmental exposure, can damage DNA and disrupt critical cellular functions. Our research investigates RECQ1, a DNA helicase that plays an essential role in maintaining DNA stability by facilitating repair processes and supporting cellular resilience under oxidative stress. This report summarizes our findings on the fundamental role of RECQ1 in DNA repair, chromatin stability, and stress response.

Our work first focused on RECQ1’s role in repairing oxidative DNA lesions, specifically 8-oxoG, a type of lesion that can lead to mutations if left unrepaired. In cells lacking RECQ1, we observed a significant accumulation of 8-oxoG lesions, suggesting that RECQ1 is actively involved in repairing oxidative DNA damage through the base excision repair (BER) pathway, one of the primary mechanisms that cells use to resolve oxidative lesions. This finding highlights the crucial role of RECQ1 in maintaining genomic integrity by preventing mutation accumulation under oxidative conditions.

In addition to its DNA repair functions, RECQ1 also plays an important role in regulating chromatin structure, which impacts gene expression. In cells without RECQ1, chromatin accessibility increased, particularly in regions associated with genes involved in cell motility and stress responses. This finding suggests that RECQ1 helps maintain chromatin stability, preventing the inappropriate activation of stress-related genes that could lead to cellular instability. Thus, RECQ1’s role extends beyond DNA repair to include chromatin remodeling, helping cells control which genes are active in response to stress.

Further analysis revealed that RECQ1 influences transcription factors—proteins that regulate gene expression under stress. Cells lacking RECQ1 showed elevated levels of c-JUN, a transcription factor that activates stress-responsive genes. This increase in c-JUN was accompanied by elevated ROS levels and proinflammatory cytokines, including IL-1β, IL-6, and TNF-α. Our findings indicate that RECQ1 serves as a buffer against excessive gene activation in response to stress, supporting cellular resilience and maintaining normal cellular functions.

We also examined RECQ1’s involvement in the response to genotoxic agents that induce both ROS production and DNA double-strand breaks (DSBs). Our results indicate that RECQ1 is critical for repairing cisplatin-induced DNA damage, thereby contributing to cellular resistance to genotoxic stress. In particular, RECQ1 facilitates DNA end resection, an essential step in the homologous recombination (HR) repair pathway, which is necessary for accurate DSB repair. This research underscores RECQ1’s multifaceted role in managing oxidative stress and promoting cellular stability.

Using TurboID, a proximity labeling method, we identified proteins that interact with RECQ1, further demonstrating its multifunctional nature. These interacting proteins are involved in key processes like DNA repair and ribosome biogenesis, highlighting RECQ1’s role in supporting cellular homeostasis beyond DNA repair. Notably, we found that RECQ1 stabilizes ribosomal DNA (rDNA) transcription, which is essential for ribosome production, a process crucial for cellular survival under stress.

Together, our findings establish RECQ1 as a central player in preserving DNA integrity and cellular stability under oxidative stress. By repairing oxidative DNA lesions, regulating chromatin structure, and controlling stress-responsive gene activation, RECQ1 helps safeguard genomic stability and maintain cellular resilience. Its involvement in diverse pathways such as DNA repair, ribosome biogenesis, and stress management offers insights into basic cellular processes, including cell cycle regulation and metabolism.

Project Outcomes and Training Impact:

This project has resulted in five peer-reviewed publications, with an additional three to four manuscripts currently in development. Newly created datasets including whole-genome, whole-transcriptome, and proximal proteome data have been or will be made publicly available, contributing to future research endeavors.

The project has directly supported the training of graduate and undergraduate students, as well as postdoctoral researchers, in experimental techniques, project design, data analysis, and professional development. Student trainees not only contributed to the project’s scientific objectives but also earned academic course credits when applicable. The research was integrated into undergraduate and graduate curricula, enabling students to present their findings at local and national conferences while fostering a diverse new generation of scientists skilled in biochemistry, cell biology, and molecular biology.

The project’s hands-on research training and mentorship were pivotal in supporting students’ aspirations for research careers. Notable achievements include (a) Undergraduate trainees securing highly competitive postbaccalaureate positions and enrolling in graduate programs; (b) Graduate student securing a faculty position; and (c) Postdoctoral fellows advancing to competitive research roles and transitioning to roles as staff researchers at external institutions. These successes underscore the broader impact of the program's mission to train underrepresented minorities in biological science research at Howard University.
